job_title: Certified Nursing Assistant CNA in Duluth, MN
pros:
I liked some residents (as will happen at any facility)
I liked some coworkers (as will happen at any facility)

We are often (most weekends) completely out of briefs and wipes. When letting management know, we were told "You don't need wipes. In old nursing, we didn't even have wipes." We were also told to go to Walmart OURSELVES and buy briefs when we had none in the facility. We were of course reimbursed but in no way is this ok. I can not say enough about the completely poor management at this facility. It is so unfair to the people who work there not to mention the residents who pay obscene amounts of money to live there. This facility has the potential to be great, but that can only happen if ALL management is fired and they start fresh with people who know what they are doing. Again, I would absolutely never recommend that anyone work there or that anyone send their family members to live there. Never been happier to quit a job.

review_title: Registered nurse: Over worked,  too much micro managing
job_title: Registered Nurse in Hammond, IN
pros:
Supportive coworkers help out with questions.
Good PTO.
cons:
Security is the worst at any hospital I've ever been to.  They are timid and lazy.  They will avoid confrontation and side with the family, throwing nurses and staff under the bus. Same can be said of nursing service. 
Usually understaffed. Management frequently hit the floor with 6-8 admissions within 4 hours.  Instead of fairly distributing admissions they just pick floor favorites.  
Computers are often broken for days or weeks or months. Other equipment and facilities out of order for months. 
Fire department banned anything to hold supplies right outside rooms. In other hospitals there are cabinets full of supplies for nurses to easily access right outside the room. 
After that, an Infectious disease nurse banned unused, sealed,  sterile supplies in rooms. So you constantly have to run back and forth to get supplies from the nurses station which is not close to most of the rooms, even then at the stations supplies are frequently not stocked. This waste a lot of time and disrupts work flow. 
They implement rules and changes without feedback from staff.  It is very top down instead of shared governance.  
Too much charting at specific times,  can get behind when you get admissions right when you can chart and to have it count. 
Upper management,  like the CEO care about only money.  He gave himself a nice ~$1 million dollar bonus last year,  bragged about it with a very prominent and public paper posting at the south campus, while nurses only had a paltry 25 cents to $1 raise an hour.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Indianapolis, IN
pros:
Friendly staff, atmosphere is good depending on the unit, management support good depending on the unit. 
Loyal staff.  Good physicians, good overall care.
cons:
Though it is overall a good place to work, they have their own problems. 
The requirements for your annual review include having 2 "accepted" Kaizens per year. If you put in 20 and only 1 is accepted, it counts against you. 
Staff is encouraged to participate in the different committees which is good unless you work nights.  Night shifters are having to come in, loose sleep. Often they are scheduled far in advance, unable to change a shift.  Not safe patient care without the proper about a sleep. 
Again, if you are not on a committee, it can be counted against you. 

There is a lot of nepotism, who knows who, in order to get an advancement.  Not always based on merit or credentials.   Which is not a healthy work environment. 

There is a problem with the turn over in the ER.

review_title: Winning the race to the bottom!
job_title: Information Services in Beech Grove, IN
pros: Here are, or at least used to be, a lot of very good people at FAIS (Franciscan Alliance Information Services). However, this company has been bleeding talent for the past 2 years and does not seem interested in understanding why or retaining the employees that have worked so hard to make FAIS a better place and provide effective and efficient solutions.
cons: From corporate to the CIO and directors there appears to be intent to drive away the best and brightest in support of a hierarchy that allows childish vendettas. Everyone I know that still works there is frustrated and looking for a way out.  The only thing that keeps them working there is that they need a job.   Do not expect help from HR unless you are one of the many close friends of the HR direct or their "in crowd".   My advice would be that if you need a job take it but understand that leadership at the director level is not interested in keeping experienced staff.  It will be a constant struggle to meet expectations and childish management style from several of the director level leaders.

review_title: Fine for entry level but limited opportunity for experienced and/or ambitious types.
job_title: Information Services in Greenwood, IN
pros:
A mission driven organization that I believe does more than pay lip service to the values it espouses.
A good place to learn about healthcare IT and information systems in general.
Good work life balance.  Very flexible and understanding when it comes to family commitments.
Generally a very stable place to work.  Difficult to get fired.
cons:
Organization is very slow moving and slow to adopt new technologies.
Ambition and risk taking are not rewarded.
While not rewarded, incompetence is overlooked.  Employees are not held to a high standard, and it shows.
This is a faith-based organization with a very conservative culture.  If that isn't you, you will not fit in.  This is especially true at the leadership levels.
Occasionally short-sited and reactive management.
Resources are often wasted on consultants and software that is poorly or never implemented.

job_title: Security Officer in Indianapolis, IN
pros: The hospital is a mostly secure position, at least in my department.  The pay is very good for armed security and deputies alike.  Uniforms are provided.  Paid Time Off is plentiful.
cons: Where do I begin?? Well, opportunity for advancement is completely non-existent. Unless of course the department heads are friends with you (kiss, kiss).  The insurance is very expensive and pay for practically no treatments.  While the pay is very good as it is, it is not on par with other health care security departments.  Oh and the upper management blindly follow advice from "consultants" whose primary cost cutting idea is too terminate numerous employees with lengthy tenures, robbing them of their earned pensions.

Remember Thanksgiving, Christmas and New Years eat up a lot of PTO), 2 pt call off after holiday (don't get sick over the holidays) and a couple other reasons to get points. Review for termination after 9 points.

They promised us a increase in pay, with great benefits. And structure.

cons:
They lied, the put us through their EMR training. Had us spend hours upon hours converting our clinic over from private practice, to Franciscan.

The provider Dr. Kim whom owned the private practice clinic (who was a amazing physican, everyone including staff and patients loved him) decided to sell to the Franciscan to make a seamless transition into EMR and the new healthcare reform. He signed a contract with them during the buy out that stated everyone must keep their position within the clinic. He decided without much notice to the staff that he had decided to go active duty in the air force, and would be shortly deploying to Korea. With that said he broke his contract with CHI. Upon doing that HR came in without notice and terminated all of us. 
It was vindictive and retaliation for dr. Kim breaking his provider contract. I have never been through something like this, it was a difficult situation for all. Including our clinical manager whom they hired, whom was employed for over 17 years with Dr. Kim. They gave her a management position. But again when they terminated our positions the reason they gave was "the position we gave you, was not really a position we have at chi"
